posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
I hope everyone has been having a great start to the school year! This summer, Team 9312 has been working on a new swerve learning minibot called TurdSwerve, which we aim to share with the FIRST Robotics Competition community. TurdSwerve is a miniaturized, fully 3D-printed swerve chassis designed to serve as an off-season bot for teams transitioning to a swerve drive next year or those looking to train newcomers and develop code. The pods are compatible with Neos, Falcons, or Kraken robots (with CIM support coming soon). The electronics are similar to a full swerve drive but use 3D-printed PLA components instead of costly COTS pods, resulting in a total cost of approximately $40 USD if spare materials are utilized. Replaceable 3D-printed gearing allows programmers to minimize screws, enhancing convenience for developers.

The robot is compact, measuring as small as 15 inches wide, making it ideal for ease-of-use and as a standalone learning tool. Teams can either import their existing swerve codebase or use TunerX-generated code, switching to TurdSwerve specifications as needed. NERDSwerve, the upgraded version, features a more durable pod design with a cost-effective swerve bearing discovered during development, remaining under $100 per robot.

An image comparing TurdSwerve and NERD Swerve is available for reference. Both designs cater to different needs, with the older TurdSwerve offering savings for those seeking affordability. A few tutorials covering Onshape modeling, assembly, and programming guides with NERDSwerve are already accessible on Team 9312’s YouTube channel, with more guides on the way. Check it out if it could benefit your team!

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Super cool. Definitely going to have to make one!!

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: It seems like you're driving it pretty hard in the demo video, how long does it last? How long can you sustain such intense driving? I'm considering whether it's something you can drive significantly, like an Alpha Bot or during off-season practice.

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: Using a full FRC battery, the Kraken is significantly more powerful than expected for a 35-pound robot. Driving at that speed typically results in a 30- to 40-minute runtime before power loss begins. A two-pod robot might sustain operation longer under similar conditions. When used for drive practice, consider the robot's compact size—it’s much easier to handle than a full-sized robot. You can extend its size by mounting it on a larger baseplate, and additional bumpers may be necessary for stability. In terms of durability, extensive use over 20 hours and participation in several events hasn’t caused any issues. Pod gearing is simple to replace if problems arise.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: this looks really great! it’s also a great advertisement for lightweighting

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: Do the gears wear out over time? How do impacts affect the modules? Also, what is the maximum weight it can support?

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: How long does it take before you need to replace the gears or other parts?

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: The text has been cleaned up by removing all unnecessary elements such as HTML tags, excessive repetition, and random images while preserving the original meaning and ensuring proper grammar and punctuation.
Is there/will there be a BOM for the 4 module version?

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: We have just updated the sheet. Sorry about that.

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: The NERDSwerve BOM features lock nuts, yet certain sections within the CAD require the use of larger or shimmed nuts due to excessive height issues."

The text is:

Hi, is the CIM option still in the plans? This could take the expense to almost zero for our team, which is rather enticing.
Either way, thanks for sharing all this!

**Cleaned Version:** Hi, is the CIM Chiaphua Industrial Motor option still in the plans? This could take the expense to almost zero for our team, which is rather enticing. Either way, thanks for sharing all this!

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: The jam nuts are needed for the extra electronics deck supports 4-pod & horizontal battery configuration. They are redundant, so they were omitted from the bill of materials. You can skip the corner stilts if you don't have jam nuts available. The CAD nuts appear identical to jam nuts since they used Onshape nuts instead.

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked:
Yes, there are still CIM and MiniCIM options available in the CAD software. The pod design matches the Neo design exactly; however, the CIM is slightly wider, causing approximately 1/16" of interference when mounted together. It should likely function well, hopefully without issues.

Unfortunately, we haven't tested the design with CIMs, so no example code is provided. Our existing Neo example code can be adapted easily for use with CIMs.

Using CIMs is technically feasible, but brushless motors are recommended due to the absence of motor encoders in CIMs, making odometry impossible—a limitation that affects autonomous programming capabilities. Nevertheless, if CIMs are handy, NERDSwerve can still assist with vision and teleop programming tasks.
Thanks! Much appreciated.

posts.name: 3061 Open Alliance Coordinator
posts.cooked: How long does it take to print all Swerve modules? What steps are needed to make this as competitive as metal Swerves? This is really cool to see; it could help many new teams!

posts.name: Maxwell Lee
posts.cooked: On our Bambulab X1C, it takes about 48 hours to print 4 pods out of PLA. The swerve pods have identical functionality as metal swerves but are likely to have durability issues when used on a 120-lb robot. The forks held up pretty well under our driving and collision tests but the gears seemed to start to wear after 20 hours of high-load driving. If you print the gears out of PA-CF or another stronger material, you might be able to play around with these drive pods on a full competition robot.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Teams have attempted full-3D printing, and while some have succeeded, many have encountered gear-related issues. Gearing failure appears to be the primary cause. It is not worth the time or resources to pursue competition bots given these challenges.

Any new decisions on what hardness to use for the wheels? It appears you've used some blue ones from your photos (50A), but most are 35A.  
Since the dual wheels cost around $15, we’re considering 50A for better longevity. Not urgent, just curious—we hope your building process is progressing well!

posts.name: Elmer Lee (head mentor)
posts.cooked: Yes, we've seen the 35A wheels wear pretty fast but they do give you a bit more traction. If you aren't trying to test max acceleration, then 50A wheels would be your better choice.

data.title: Introducing NERDSwerve: A Miniature, 3D-Printed Swerve Learning Chassis
